author: jakrypto.
content: Hi guys, quick question. Since after the merge every validator needs to run an execution client, shouldn't there be a massive increase in eth1 full nodes prior the merge? We have only 5300 fully synced full nodes atm

author: jakrypto.
content: As far as I understand, 3rd party solutions (infura etc.) won't work after the merge

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: They'll keep working just fine: if you're running a validator on a cloud compute platform you can point to Infura rather than running an EL client yourself, I believe.

author: jakrypto.
content: I thought this won't be possible due to changes in the block production mechanism

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: It's similar to how in PoW, mining pools can run very few EL clients, with many ASICs and GPUs performing the hashing connected to a single client.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: The EL client needs to distribute the blocks to the ASICs, GPUs in time for them to get to work. Similarly under PoS, the CL clients need provide attestations and to propose blocks.

author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: [I don't have a high degree in confidence in my response; this is my mental model however so keen to be corrected]

author: ajsutton
content: You will need to run your own EL post-merge.  The CL client is in charge of selecting the correct chain so you can't reliably have multiple CLs using the same EL (or they'd potentially give it conflicting information about which chain is canonical).

author: jakrypto.
content: Ok, but how do we achieve that without issues? We will have around 300k validators which need to sync the current state prior to the merge... Will there be snapshots offered by a trusted source?

author: pietjepuk
content: You can just sync as you have always been able to, what's wrong with that? Also, there's definitely not 300k validator clients running. Most have multiple validators loaded.

author: bridge-bot
content: <dankrad> there are 300k validators but running on a few thousand nodes
